sentence.text: Lord Mayor , people with disabilities detest being patronised .
He detested starting the day with an argument .
I had enjoyed Hope and the work we did at night , but I detested working at night , as I had never managed to sleep well during the day .
He is generally fed microfeed with sugar beet , and he loves carrots and sugar , but he detests his feed being mixed .
The Shah detested the way in which mossadeq rather than he was coming to symbolize Iran , and he tried in the summer of 1952 to remove him from office .

How she detested men like this .
Perdita and Trace had detested each other on sight and , together with Randy , Trace spent a lot of time when they were n't screwing , winding Perdita up .
She detested Topaz for exactly the same reason and her constant nagging had made Loverin 's mind up for him .
It was well known amongst that elite of which he was a part that the Chairman detested news of crisis .
You respected his motives but detested his vanity . "
` George Galloway is detested by everybody around 'ere , " she answered him .

No wonder he was so universally detested .
I detest the Sevillian architect Roberto Luna whose armour-plated chamber shields the obscene dance that is ` Guernica " .
I detest the American critic Dore Ashton who rightly declared that Guernica' is not contemporary art but history " .
After all , he detested physical pain and discomfort -- and this excursion had promised both .
He so detested the word ` Enterprise " , with its ring of commerce , that at Poindexter 's trial he scolded the prosecutor every time he used it .
We detest you so much we will bribe you to go away . "

Mr Ceausescu is certainly detested in Moscow as much as in London or Washington .

When Cosmo and Hubert were in Perthshire she would be back in the ambience she detested .

He gave her the gleaming smile she detested .
